Posts.Content: I am a single lady of 42 and am currently doing chemo on my own.   I have a few close friends who I have made an extra effort to stay in touch with as they have been great when needing company during chemo and keeping up social contact while I am unable to work.  I had three rounds of AC chemo first, which made me very poorly but friends and family were on the end of a phone call to support me emotionally. I didn't feel like I wanted anyone around in person during those days when I took to my bed but it was lovely having people texting to check in, knowing I may not get back to them right away. I also have a private Facebook group with a specially selected group of friends and family where I share updates and a few giggles.
Posts.Title: on your own with breast cancer chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I have found this whole experience a revelation as far as showing me that I have people in my life on whom I can rely for help and support in time of crisis. I'm so glad you have that too. All the best xxx
Posts.Title: on your own with breast cancer chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Just wanted to add that another tumour can also appear elsewhere in the body and it will not necessarily have the same hormonal characteristics as the original one. You may want to explore non hormonal birth control such as the coil.  Best wishes getting good advice from your gp and in making a good decision for you xxx
Posts.Title: Taking the pill after cancer?

Posts.Content: @Frankies_Ducky congratulations! So pleased for you. I was relieved when my genetic results came back clear as well. If you don't have any of the related faulty genes then the risk of a new cancer should be way less than 50 per cent though. Did one of the other genes come up positive?
Posts.Title: A bit of good news

Posts.Content: Hi, just popped in to say there isn't a hurry to make this decision right now. Consider having the radiotherapy then if you decide to have the mastectomy later on the option is still available. Best wishes in your decision making and much hugs from across the oceans xxx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy or propheitic double mastectomy

Posts.Content: Thanks Carolyn, I am nearly done with chemo and will have to remember not to get too tense if my hair doesn't reappear on schedule!
Posts.Title: Of hair regrowth after chemo ....

Posts.Content: "Bum trumpet"! Hahahahaha! Love it   Seriously though, to make fun of a cancer patient, what a lowlife.  And gosh, people display such a lack of imagination when it comes to women with short hair. If dark it's Sinead O'Connor, if blonde it's Annie Lennox! Sending you hair growth vibes, across the oceans xxx
Posts.Title: Of hair regrowth after chemo ....

Posts.Content: Tebs I think you make some really good points. Not sure if the marketing people really thought Shave for a Cure through properly. Yep, losing all your body hair is crap. Must say I don't miss my leg and underarm hair but surprisingly I do not like the rather sad state of my ladygarden! There must be better ways to raise the money, I agree.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: The ads I dislike the most are the ones that imply that after completion of cancer treatment one is then cured and then life goes on as normal or better than before. I'm sure this is what most people think anyway but it doesn't need reinforcement as it's completely inaccurate.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I have just one more to go after being on chemo since March. So close I can taste it! Planning celebratory drinks as I too feel like this is the end of the hardest part, even though I still have radiotherapy and surgery to come. Hoorah to you, and to me, and much hugs from across the oceans! xxx
Posts.Title: chemo finish line approaching

Posts.Content: Hooray Sammystaff, not far to go now! Hugs and best wishes xxx
Posts.Title: chemo finish line approaching

Posts.Content: It is difficult talking about poo with a medical professional at the best of times isn't it. I've recently also been very fed up of having no control over my own body and life.  My oncologist is younger than me and I have a little crush on him so that makes it very awkward to bring up bodily functions! My diet right now is down to pizza, crisps and icecream as I have lost the appetite for so many other foods. Go easy on yourself and hugs across the oceans to you xxx
Posts.Title: GREAT TIMING......

Posts.Content: It is difficult talking about poo with a medical professional at the best of times isn't it. I've recently also been very fed up of having no control over my own body and life.  My oncologist is younger than me and I have a little crush on him so that makes it very awkward to bring up bodily functions! My diet right now is down to pizza, crisps and icecream as I have lost the appetite for so many other foods. Go easy on yourself and hugs across the oceans to you xxx
Posts.Title: GREAT TIMING......

Posts.Content: Good for you Maggie, I have found my wig to be invaluable in helping me feel more normal and confident when out and about. I didn't spend much money on it, and got a contribution towards it from a charity here, and the rest paid for by the hospital that has a wig fund. Maybe there's something similar over there if you ask around. Everyone who has seen me in it loves it and can't believe it's not my real hair!
Posts.Title: How big is your lump?

Posts.Content: Hi Maggie, mine is 70mm, plus some odd bits of calcification.  Like others have said, size is not the only thing that affects prognosis. How fast it is growing and whether there is spread to the lymph nodes are also key, and whether it is hormone receptive. Best thing to do in my opinion would be to go over all your results so far with the breast surgeon or oncologist. Take a list of questions and a friend who can help you listen and take notes. Best wishes and much hugs xxx
Posts.Title: How big is your lump?

Posts.Content: Tumour cell necrosis is not a good thing.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Snowys Mum, I wasn't trying to convince Chloecat. I was offering my thoughts to the group for what they are worth. And yes, I do know that breast cancer takes women who follow the conventional path, it took my mum at age 46. I'm also sure it takes many more who don't follow that path. Whether we do or do not we will remain in fear that it may recurr or metastasize. Alternative treatments do not remove the fear. Good luck to anyone who wants to take another path, but I am afraid I am on the side of those who believe our medical teams know what they are talking about and I intend to end this year having at least removed the cancer with which I started it.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Interesting. I only hope others are not looking at Chloecat's story and thinking it represents a real alternative. I guess I have been lucky as my surgical and oncological team have been so lovely and inspired such trust in me that I know for myself that the only other option ends in my premature death. AFAICT, SPDT is not effective for most BC and not for locally advanced breast cancer. www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/types/surgery/photodynamic-fact-sheet
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: @ronstar don't sell yourself short, anyone who has been through breast cancer and the necessary treatment has all the courage anyone could wish for! To put your trust in the expertise of others takes tremendous courage.  Best wishes and much hugs xxx
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: This is definitely a thing. I remember my Mum's hair which was normally just wavy, grew back very curly after chemo.  Hopefully others have tips on how to manage it. Best wishes xxx
Posts.Title: Hair a fuzz ball

Posts.Content: Thank you to ronstar, you made me chuckle! Glad I am not the only one freaking out about this!
Posts.Title: Nails lifting off!

Posts.Content: I thought I had found out everything I could regarding the chemo side effects, however I was just informed by my oncologist this week that the reason my fingertips are feeling tender is that the nails are starting to lift away from the nailbeds! The idea of my naiks lifting off completely squicks me out! Has this happened to you and if so was it painful? How do you manage with no naik?
Posts.Title: Nails lifting off!

Posts.Content: Hey, g'day! Thanks for the advice about taping them down, hasn't quite got to that stage yet but can definitely see a colour change under a couple of fingernails and have two black toenails. Hoping they will hang on to the end of chemo in 3 and a bit weeks. Fingers crossed!
Posts.Title: Nails lifting off!

Posts.Content: Just to say that the criteria is not always wholly based on number of affected family members. I was able to access genetic testing, with only one blood relative (my mum) affected. The circumstances were slightly unusual as we were both young upon diagnosis (40 and 42).
Posts.Title: Axillary tail lump.

Posts.Content: Hi there Tilla Mine took about 8 weeks to come back, from Peter Mac Cancer centre in Melbourne. Not sure of usual turnaround in UK. I believe mine had to be sent to US for testing.  They gathered all my family history, such as I could provide, beforethe counseling appointment and didn't go looking for medical records as none of my family records exist in Australia. I had several death certificates from family history research done previously which came in handy.
Posts.Title: Axillary tail lump.

Posts.Content: Yeah, I don't feel like it will be over when the treatment is over either. Can you get put in touch with a counselor who will help you talk over all those residual feelings with? Much hugs from across the oceans xxx
Posts.Title: Well that’s that
